Last Saturday afternoon, just
before the lacrosse tilt, the track
team suffered defeat at the hands
of the Blue and Gold by a score
of 93-32. Hopkins took only two
first places, Joe Thompson pointing the way in the 220-yard hurdles and Clarke winning the 220yard dash. Aaronson put up an
excellent brand of pole-vaulting
and, even though he went two
inches above the old Hopkins record of 11 feet 7 inches, he failed
to take first honors. _McLean, of
Navy, the winner of this event,
also broke the record of the Academy when he cleared 11 feet 11%
inches.
Curtis ran- the mile in the fast
time of 4 minutes 23 1-5 seconds,
with his teammate, Hurd, second,
and Verne Booth, third. Booth
also took second in the 880. Aaronson and Clarke finished second
and third, respectively, in the 100yard dash, while Dorcas and Edwards repeated the same in the
quarter. Corning was given second place in the high hurdles
when the two first men were disqualified. Other places garnered
by Hopkins were a third in the
discus throw by Hambleton, and
second place in the broad jump
by Aaronson.
The mile relay team put up a
game fight, even though the first
three runners were well-nigh tired
out by previous events. Thompson, running first, had already
participated in three events. Edwards and Dorcas had also each
run a quarter mile -m short time
before, and still felt the effects of
it. Norwood, the only fresh Hopkins man, finished about thirty
yards behind Curtis, who ran anchor for Navy. The time of the
race was 3 minutes 28-3-5 seconds.
Aaronson, with a total of nine
points, was the highest point-winner for the Black and Blue, while
Hudson scored eight points for
Navy.

At a meeting of the Tau Beta
Pi Honorary Engineering Fraternity last Thursday evening a
number of alumni and undergraduate students in the School of Engineering were initiated into the
society. It was the policy of the
society in choosing these men not
only to take in deserving men
now in the University, but also to
take those graduates who were
worthy of membership before a
chapter was installed at Hopkins.

Massachusels Institute of Technology
School of
Chemical Engineering Practice
.

A graduate school with stations established in industrial
plants located at Bangor, Maine, Boston Mass., and
Buffalo, New York, where the field of chemical engineering is studied systematically on large-scale apparatus
and where instruttion is given in the application of
chemical and chemical engineering theor9 to practice.

The total number admitted to the School is limited
,and the students, studying and experimenting in small
groups, receive individual attention.
.
Before admittance to the School of Chemical Engineering Practice all students must have adequate preparation
in chemistr9 and engineering. The able student can
complete the requirements for the Master of Science
Degree in one and a half Years.

Last Saturday afternoon, just
before the lacrosse tilt, the track
team suffered defeat at the hands
of the Blue and Gold by a score
of 93-32. Hopkins took only two
first places, Joe Thompson pointing the way in the 220-yard hurdles and Clarke winning the 220yard dash. Aaronson put up an
excellent brand of pole-vaulting
and, even though he went two
inches above the old Hopkins record of 11 feet 7 inches, he failed
to take first honors. _McLean, of
Navy, the winner of this event,
also broke the record of the Academy when he cleared 11 feet 11%
inches.
Curtis ran- the mile in the fast
time of 4 minutes 23 1-5 seconds,
with his teammate, Hurd, second,
and Verne Booth, third. Booth
also took second in the 880. Aaronson and Clarke finished second
and third, respectively, in the 100yard dash, while Dorcas and Edwards repeated the same in the
quarter. Corning was given second place in the high hurdles
when the two first men were disqualified. Other places garnered
by Hopkins were a third in the
discus throw by Hambleton, and
second place in the broad jump
by Aaronson.
The mile relay team put up a
game fight, even though the first
three runners were well-nigh tired
out by previous events. Thompson, running first, had already
participated in three events. Edwards and Dorcas had also each
run a quarter mile -m short time
before, and still felt the effects of
it. Norwood, the only fresh Hopkins man, finished about thirty
yards behind Curtis, who ran anchor for Navy. The time of the
race was 3 minutes 28-3-5 seconds.
Aaronson, with a total of nine
points, was the highest point-winner for the Black and Blue, while
Hudson scored eight points for
Navy.

groups, receive individual attention.

The Silver Arrow Club announces with great pleasure the
pledging of Lawrence R. Houston, '25, of Narberth, Pa.
Every member of Princeton's
basket-ball team, which won the
intercollegiate championship, will
return to college next year. The
senior class had been represented
by only three men, the captain and
two "subs," but as not one of them
played regularly their loss will not
be felt.
